newsitem.title: FRANCE: FOCUS-Northwest in MOU for 50 Airbus jets.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Northwest in MOU for 50 Airbus jets.

text.p: European aircraft consortium Airbus Industrie said on Thursday that U.S. carrier Northwest Airlines had signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) for 50 firm orders and up to 100 options on A319 jets.
The value of the 50 aircraft is estimated at about $2 billion, based on an average price of around $40 million for an A319. The MOU is a commitment to buy rather than a firm order.
Airbus said delivery of the 125-seat, twin-engine jets are scheduled for 1999 through 2003.
"We are hopeful that this memorandum of understanding will result in a final agreement in the near future," Airbus quoted John Dasburg, Northwest's chief executive officer, as saying.
The A319 is a smaller version of the A320 and A321. All three aircraft feature identical flight decks and the widest passenger cabins of any single aisle aircraft, Airbus said.
Northwest currently operates 50 A320s and has an additional previously announced contract for 20 A320s to be delivered in 1998 and 1999.
Airbus is a consortium made up of French state-owned Aerospatiale, British Aerospace Plc, Daimler-Benz Aerospace, a unit of Daimler-Benz AG, and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA (CASA) of Spain.
